'''HMS ''Lee''''' was a 20-gun [[Cyrus class post ship|''Cyrus''-class]] [[sixth-rate]] [[post ship]] of the [[Royal Navy]] built in 1814 by Josiah and Thomas Brindley, nephews to [[Lord Nelson]], at one of their [[Shipbuilding in Frindsbury, Kent|three yards]] in [[Frindsbury]] in [[Kent]].

The ''Lee'' was first commissioned in January 1815 under Captain James Bremer. Following the end of the [[Napoleonic Wars]], in August 1815 Captain [[John Pasco]] was given command of HMS ''Lee'' and was employed in the [[English Channel]] for the suppression of smuggling. He remained her captain until ''Lee'' was [[Ship commissioning#Ship decommissioning|paid off]] in September 1818. ''Lee'' was retained in [[Reserve Fleet (United Kingdom)|ordinary]] for another four years before she was sold for breaking up in May 1822.
